introduction.p:
Recall that in chapter 7 we defined an exponential function to be a function of the form
P=P(t)=a(\alert{b})^t.
In this section we will discuss logarithmic functions which are inverses of exponential functions. In particular, the function t=\log_{\alert{b}}(\frac{P}{a}) is the inverse of the exponential function above.
For a=1, the following applet illustrates this inverse relationship:

figure.caption: Explore the inverse relationship between between the functions f(t)=\log_b(t) and g(t)=b^t for various values of b>0 with this applet.

introduction.p: While this inverse relationship is how we will think of logarithms in practice, let's give a formal definition:

assemblage.title: The Logarithm
assemblage.p: Let b\neq 1 be a positive number, then the function f(t)=\log_b(t) is called a logarithm with base b .
Upon inputting a value t the function \log_b(t) will tell you the power of b which will yield t .

introduction.p:
Due to the relationship between logarithms and exponentials, we often say that the equations
x=\log_b(y)\ \ \ \ \text{and}\ \ \ \ b^x=y are equivalent.

warning.p:
One of the more common bases of a logarithm is base 10 . Since it is used so often, we have developed a short hand notation for a logarithm of base 10. This short hand is shown below:
\log_{10}(y)=\log(y).
In other words, we simply drop the subscript when referring to base 10 .

subsection.title: Properties of Logarithms

assemblage.title: Properties of Logarithms
assemblage.p:
If x,y,b>0, and b\neq 1, then
\log_b(xy)=\log_b(x)+\log_b(y),
\log_b\frac{x}{y}=\log_b(x)-\log_b(y),
\log_b(x^k)=k\cdot \log_b(x),
\log_b(b^y)=y,
b^{\log_b(x)}=x.

subsection.p: We will examine the properties of logarithms closer in the Homework problems. For now, study the examples below, keeping in mind that a logarithm is is the inverse function of an exponential function.

subsection.title: Using the Properties of Logarithms
subsection.p: Of course, these properties are useful not so much for computing logs but rather for simplifying expressions that contain variables. We will use them to solve exponential equations. But first, we will practice applying the properties. In the next Example, we rewrite one log in terms of simpler logs.

solution.p: First, we write \sqrt{xy} using a fractional exponent: \log_{b}{\sqrt{xy}} = \log_{b}{((xy)^{1/2})}. Then we apply Property (3) to rewrite the exponent as a coefficient: \log_{b}{((xy)^{1/2})} = \frac{1}{2}\log_{b}{(xy)}. Finally, by Property (1) we write the log of a product as a sum of logs: \frac{1}{2}(\log_{b}{xy}) = \frac{1}{2}(\log_{b}{x} + \log_{b}{y}). Thus, \log_{b}\sqrt{xy} = \frac{1}{2}(\log_{b}{x} + \log_{b}{y}).

warning.p:
Be careful when using the properties of logarithms! Compare the statements below:
\log_{b}{(2x)} = \log_{b}{2} + \log_{b}{x} \ \ \ \text{ by Property 1,}
but
\log_{b}{(2 + x)} \ne \log_{b}{2} + \log_{b}{x}.
\log_{b}{\left(\dfrac{x}{5}\right)}= \log_b x - \log_b 5 \ \ \ \text{ by Property 2,}
but
\log_{b}{\left(\dfrac{x}{5}\right)} \ne \dfrac{\log_b x}{\log_b 5}.

subsection.p: We can also use the properties of logarithms to combine sums and differences of logarithms into one logarithm.

statement.p: Express 3(\log_b x - \log_b y) as a single logarithm with a coefficient of 1.

solution.p: We begin by applying Property (2) to combine the logs. 3(\log_b x - \log_b y) = 3 \log_{b}\left(\frac{x}{y}\right) Then, using Property (3), we replace the coefficient 3 by an exponent 3. 3 \log_{b}\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)=\log_{b}\left(\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)^3\right)

statement.p: Express 2\log_b x + 4\log_{b}{(x + 3)} as a single logarithm with a coefficient of 1.

subsection.title: The Natural Exponential Function
subsection.p: There is another base for logarithms and exponential functions that is often used in applications. This base is an irrational number called e, where e \approx 2.71828182845. The number e is essential for many advanced topics, and it is often called the natural basenatural base.
The base e logarithm of a number x, or \log_ e x, is called the natural logarithmnatural logarithm of x and is denoted by \ln x.

assemblage.title: The Natural Logarithm
assemblage.p: The natural logarithm is the logarithm base e. \ln x = \log_{e}{x}, ~~~~ x\gt 0

subsection.p: We use natural logarithms in the same way that we use logs to other bases. The properties of logarithms that we studied above also apply to logarithms base e.

subsection.title: Solving Exponential Equations
subsection.p: Suppose we want to solve the equation 5^x = 7. We could rewrite the equation in logarithmic form to obtain the exact solution x = \log_{5}{7}. However, sometimes we are stuck in a situation where we cannot evaluate \log_{5}{7}. For example, some calculators do not have a log base 5 button. So, if we want a decimal approximation for the solution, we begin by taking the base 10 logarithm of both sides of the original equation, even though the base of the power is not 10. This gives us \log_{10}{(5^x)} = \log_{10}{7}. Then we use Property (3) to rewrite the left side as x \log_{10}{5} = \log_{10}{7}. Note how using Property (3) allows us to solve the equation: The variable, x, is no longer in the exponent, and it is multiplied by a constant, \log_{10}{5}. To finish the solution, we divide both sides by \log_{10}{5} to get x = \frac{\log_{10}{7}}{\log_{10}{5}}. On your calculator, enter the sequence

warning.p: Do not confuse the expression \dfrac{\log_{10}{7}}{\log_{10}{5}} with \log_{10}{\left(\dfrac{7}{5}\right)}; they are not the same! Property (2) allows us to simplify \log{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)}, but not \dfrac{\log x}{\log y}. We cannot rewrite \dfrac{\log_{10}{7}}{\log_{10}{5}}, so we must evaluate it as (\log 7)/(\log 5). You can check on your calculator that \dfrac{\log_{10}{7}}{\log_{10}{5}}\ne \log_{10}{\left(\dfrac{7}{5}\right)}= \log_{10}{1.4}.

solution.p: First we divide both sides by 80 to obtain 20.5 = 6^{0.03x}. Next, we take the base 10 logarithm of both sides of the equation and use Property (3) of logarithms to get \log_{10}{20.5} = \log_{10}{(6^{0.03x})}= 0.03x \log_{10}{6}. On the right side of the equation, x is multiplied by two constants, 0.03 and \log_{10}{6}. So, to solve for x we must divide both sides of the equation by 0.03 \log_{10}{6}. We use a calculator to evaluate the answer: x = \frac{\log_{10}{20.5}}{0.03 \log_{10}{6}}\approx 56.19. (On your calculator, remember to enclose the denominator, 0.03 \log_{10}{6}, in parentheses.)
